Shooting Duration
Squadron Speed
System Improvement [industryColored] cost on Systems orbited by Behemoth
+20 [scienceColored] on Colonized Planets with Anomalies on System
Inquisitive Collection
This collection focuses on war-time science.
Staunch Collection
This collection focuses on ground combat.
Patriotic Collection
This collection bonuses on manpower and influence.
Insightful Collection
This collection focuses on science.
Swarm Tactics
15% more Troops on Ground Battle
0.1 [scienceColored] per [foodColored] on Systems
+10% to Ground Troop [health]
+10% Ground Troop Damage
+10% Influence radius size
Improvements are 35% less likely to be destroyed during Invasions
Comfortable Loyalty
Peculiar Cuisine
The Bhagaba introduce methods that coincidentally seem to help with spreading the envy of your delicious and unique food.
0.05 [prestigeColored] per [foodColored] on Systems
+3 [dustColored] per [population] on Sterile Planets
Academy Contributions are worth 20% more
Dust Attunement
A history of Endless genetic alteration for Dust sensitivity allows the dredging of Dust even on the most lush and verdant planets.
Fervent belief in the mission of Isyander and the Lost increases contributions to the Academy by 20%
No [fids] penalty on Temples of the Lost
Rapid Deployment
Superior logistics allow you to quickly organize the deployment of heroes. While the heroes may not appreciate your efficiency, their flexibility is truly something to be envied.
Diligent Collection
This collection focuses on Money and Ground Combat

Nakalim Ground Battle Offense Strategy Unlocked: Precision A2G Strikes (improved "Preemptive Bombing" that allows for deploying additional troops and additional bombardment damage) Nakalim Ground Battle Offense Strategy Unlocked: Manipular Formation Tactics (improved "Guerilla" with better troop health and a lower troop damage penalty)
Precision A2G Strikes
Long experience with orbital bombardment allows for more precise placement of munitions, causing greater damage to the enemy without risking shelling your own troops.
Manipular Formation Tactics
Ancient arts of ground warfare refined over the long height of your empire allows for the engagement of any type of enemy in any terrain without significant losses.
Echo Foundation

Many spatio-temporal anomalies are not mere examples of statistical happenstance, but are consequences of prior habitation by the Lost, during their heyday. Frequently, they even exhibit fleeting remnants of primordial dust, and thus, latent fragments of the consciousness of the Lost who touched these sites. As much of the Nakalim's native "technology" interfaces directly with the Lost and their dust, these sites can trigger surprising activations and 'echoes' inside any artifacts of that era - all of which is a wealth of opportunity for knowledge about the subject.
Unlock $TechToUnlock3 and $TechToUnlock4 technologies
Unlock $TechToUnlock3 and $TechToUnlock4 technologies
Kamdir Martial School

Founded by the late King Kamdir, these schools train the local populace in self defense and raise up the best among them to become the Temple Guard. Following years of training and an intense ritual exposure to the contents of certain Relics, the Temple Guard no longer require speech to communicate with their comrades, and are finally allowed to protect the Relics, the Temples, and their worshipers.
+10% Defending troops health per Temple on System
+25 [prestigeColored] per Planet without Temple on System
+10 [happinessColored] per Temple on System
+50 [industryColored] per Temple on System
+50 [dustColored] per Temple on System
Unlock $TechToUnlock and $Tech2ToUnlock technologies
+15 [foodcolored] on System +15 [industrycolored] on System
+10 [foodcolored] on System +10 [industrycolored] on System -15% System Improvement [industrycolored] Cost on System
Troop Irritator
-75 [manpowerColored]

This module, specially made for the Academy and by the Academy, is dedicated to wasting as much space as possible and making your soldiers have a terrible time in their bunkers. This is so effective in fact, that the number of crew that can be stationed in this ship is vastly decreased.
[juggernaut] Behemoth
[juggernaut] Military Behemoth

With access to both ancient and recent studies and data, the Librarian can find answers to difficult questions, discover advanced technologies, and highly effectively infiltrate networks.

The Librarian can access hidden information only available to the Academy, such as data on the state of heroes and other empires, critical hacking vulnerabilities in network protocols, and a cache of scientific information enabling the research of technologies one stage higher than normal.

The Master of Dust holds the keys to the Academy's vaults--within limits, of course--and can use this wealth to affect diplomatic actions. The Master of Dust also gains the Academy's support when dealing in trade and diplomacy, allowing free trade deals and the imposing of peaceful relations on otherwise intractable empires.

The Master of Dust can make grants with the Academy's funds, and has access to the Academy's extensive business communications network and contacts making all trade deals effectively free and enabling them to force peaceful relations.
The Spear of Isyander is the leader of the Academy fleets and personally directs one of the largest, as well as gaining access to Academy gunners and squadron pilots.
The Spear of Isyander may command the Academy attack Master Fleet directly, and gains +5% module damage per unlocked military era.
The Vault Keeper does not guard Academy treasures, but manages a vast, secure infrastructure that tracks the rules and regulations of the galaxy. This position confers increased political prominence.
The Vault Keeper has access to all the laws of an additional party of his choice (with the exception of the super-law), and influence radius gains are increased by 10% empire-wide.
I expected fleets of ships, not an offer of peace. I will not hide the Aurigans' feeling of relief.

The construction of nano-machines--or nanites--capable of operating in liquid environments with various conditions of salinity, temperature, pressure, and microbial life has a range of potential applications. Research into energy sources, locomotion, and self-repair enables a whole ecology of these liquid nanites to be developed.
Nano Aquaculture

The construction of Church approved nano-machines--or nanites--capable of operating in liquid environments with various conditions of salinity, temperature, pressure, and microbial life has a range of potential applications. Research into energy sources, locomotion, and self-repair enables a whole ecology of these liquid nanites to be developed.
Mining Probes can collect FIDS resources of a planet and add them to the Home System's resource generation.
Outpost [foodColored]/[industryColored] Stockpile Siege Damage / [turn]
Critical Damage taken
Garrison the fleet and dock it into the hangar of the current start system to quickly repair and restock. You may only garrison your own star system.
Garrison
Maintain $AmountLoc [militaristColored] #B82738#Militarist#REVERT# Law(s) for $DurationName [turn].
To increase Militarist Political ideology: build ships, defense, be aggressive with other factions.

Food production increases population Normal Consumption Formula: (Population Using Food + (Population Using Double Food * 2)) / (300 * Game Speed Modifier) Vodyani Consumption Formula: ((System Food ^ 1.25) / 1200 / Game Speed Modifier * 2) - 1% per Vodyani Population Horatio population consume twice as much food

Food production increases population Normal Consumption Formula: (Population Using Food + (Population Using Double Food * 2)) / (300 * Game Speed Modifier) Vodyani Consumption Formula: ((System Food ^ 1.25) / 1200 / Game Speed Modifier * 2) - 1% per Vodyani Population Horatio population consume twice as much food
Industry is used to build Improvements and Ships on this System. Industry not used the turn it is produced, gets saved for one turn, and added onto the next turn.

Putting a unit of Population in this slot will create Overpopulation penalties for the System Approval. Disapproval Formula = (Overpopulation Threshold - (Maximum Population * Percentage of Overpopulated Population)) * 3.75

Putting units of Population in these slots will create Overpopulation penalties for the System Approval. Disapproval Formula = (Overpopulation Threshold - (Maximum Population * Percentage of Overpopulated Population)) * 3.75

Influence increases Influence zones around the system, and is the currency for Diplomacy. Influence Radius Formula = ((System Influence / Game Speed Multiplier) / [pi])^0.4 / (1.5 + (50 / System Influence))

Influence increases Influence zones around the system, and is the currency for Diplomacy. Law Initial Cost is Law Level multiplied by whichever is higher: 5 OR 20% of your net influence generated per turn
Influence increases Influence zones around systems, and is the currency for Diplomacy.

Science is used by the empire to research new technologies. Tech Cost Formula = (((1 + Total Techs Researched * 3)^1.05 - Total Techs Researched + 15) * 2)^1.25 * Era Multiplier Era Multipliers = 1.25, 2, 7.5, 20, 50, 50

Lists active Trading Companies and Trade Routes Base Trade HQ Income = 250 * (4.2) ^ Number of Trading Locations * (0.75 + Trading Company Level / 35 ^ 0.75) * Trade Value (For Luxury resources, multiply by (abundance * 0.025)) Luxury Resource Income from a subsidiary is reduced by 20% (or 40% if both trading locations are subsidiaries) Total population, abundance and rarity of Luxuries, distance between trade locations are the most important factors for determining Trade Value. Some System Development Upgrades and System Improvements can vastly improve Trade Value. Putting a HQ or Subsidiary adjacent to another HQ or Subsidiary reduces your luxury resource income by 40% Trading with an ally reduces luxury resource trade income by 10%, Trading with someone you are at peace with reduces luxury income by 40% Science and Dust income efficiency are determined by the quantity of Dust and Science improvements respectively. Trade HQ experience is determined by how much money it makes.
Broadside Weapon
This is a Broadside slot; a weapon placed here will have two firing arcs of 120 degrees centred directly to the left and right of the ship.
Turret Weapon
This is a Turret slot; a weapon placed here will have a firing arc of 270 degrees centred directly forward of the ship.
Heavy Weapon

This is a Heavy Slot; Heavy mounts hold a single large weapon with four times the damage and half the fire rate of a regular weapon mount, effectively twice the DPS. Flak weapons are much less effective against missiles and squadrons in this slot.
Spectator
The invisible, unkillable, all-seeing faction that can't do anything.
Fearmongering
+30 [scienceColored] per [population] type.
+7 [happinessColored] per [population] type.
You can use Alt + Click to force a technology to the top of the queue.
While watching a Space Battle, you can accelerate (+), slow down (-) or pause (Pause) the sequence. You can still navigate with the Free Camera.
To Colonize a System, you must first create an Outpost on one of its planets, and populate it using Outpost Actions (You can't put an outpost on an occupied system).
Exploration ships can use Probes either on planets with Curiosities to reveal them or be sent out into space to look in places your ships can't reach.
You can activate the tutorial at any time through the game options.
The border of your empire grows depending on the Influence [influencecolored] production of your systems. The more a system produces, the faster its border expands.
Each political ideology provides a mandatory law, guiding your strategy. In addition, you can vote more laws from the elected parties.
Cravers [Cravers] start as an Autocracy. Only a single party is permitted in the Senate, only the Main Population votes, and Anarchy cannot occur.

Your system can be improved by selecting a specialization once you have unlocked the proper technology. Developing a system consumes a set ammount of the selected luxury resource and provides a permanent boost. Be careful how you specialize your empire as specializations cannot be changed.
Trading Companies are created by building a Headquarters. It will then create Trade Routes from the star system it’s located in to all systems with a Subsidiary.
You can invest in a Trade Company from the Economy Screen in order to increase their Trade Routes' income.
Minor Civilizations provide a Faction Trait once assimilated. You can assimilate through war, by using your Influence [influencecolored] or through a quest.

A part of your growth is converted to empire manpower [manpower] every turn. Empire Manpower is then permanently moved to your ships becoming Ship Manpower [ShipCrew] and to your systems becoming System Manpower [SystemDefense], both of which are used to generate troops, tanks and planes during ground battle.
Once a Behemoth [Juggernaut] is turned into Citadel [Citadel], it cannot be moved or scrapped.
The more Behemoth [Juggernaut] technologies you research, the more Behemoths you'll be able to control.
Any Behemoth [Juggernaut] can be specialized into any type of Behemoth specialization; a support Behemoth can become a Juggernaut.
The Strategic Resource cost to fire an Obliterator [Obliterator] decreases each turn, eventually reaching zero.
Combine a Citadel [Citadel] and an System Shield to completely negate any damage from Obliterator missiles, though only once as both will be consumed in the process.
Regular Technologies' icons are circles, Deeds are diamonds and Behemoth techs are hexagons.
Keii [Honorcolored] is a Hissho [MajorHisshos] exclusive resource and is generated by winning Space and Ground Battles, by completing Deeds and Quests and by finding systems.
The Hissho [MajorHisshos] will lose Keii [Honorcolored] if they retreat from a Battle.
Hissho [MajorHisshos] take longer to settle an Outpost, and the process must be completed by using Keii [Honorcolored] (the cost in Keii decreases each turn, but is never 0).
Thanks to the Hissho [MajorHisshos] Affinity, population is able to live on any planet without suffering penalty.
As Umbral Choir [UmbralChoir] always be sure to have at least one active Transmigration Beacon. You never know when an enemy fleet may come knocking!
As Umbral Choir [UmbralChoir], all your ships are naturally Cloaked. Even the ones you buy on the Marketplace!
As Umbral Choir [UmbralChoir], the more Sanctuaries you have on a system, the higher your cloaking level and the more difficult it is for your enemies to detect.
As Umbral Choir [UmbralChoir], your Sanctuaries will help your allies in their Ground Battles. Being the Umbral Choir and being a pal are not incompatible!
Any Backdoor you place will grant you a small [hackingSpeed] Hacking Speed bonus when Hacking through its node.
Starting a Hacking Op from a Backdoor will never trigger a security breach. This does not mean there are no Defensive Programs on the node though!
Unallocated Bandwidth will grant you a small [hackingSpeed] Hacking Speed bonus.
Hacking a Home System yields much better outcomes than a regular System. Don't forget to defend yours appropriately!
Blockading an empty Star System will prevent most factions from being able to colonize it
Make sure you use your influence [influencecolored]. Laws are very powerful tools you don’t want to be missing out on.
Sophons [Sophons] have excellent ships, with each ship having an extra slot with no limitations.
Quality over quantity! Horatio’s [Horatio] ships have one less module slot and are more expensive than other faction’s ships, but their existing weapon modules deal bonus damage.
The Lumeris [Lumeris] can colonize any system they can see, regardless of if their ships can actually travel there.
Every faction has a unique behemoth module available to them on the Juggernaut Blueprints technology.
Bombers [Bomber] are powerful weapons for taking out larger ships quickly; make sure you don’t neglect them.
Trade Companies are an effective way to increase your luxury resource and Dust production, though they can be expensive to upgrade.
Food [food] is important not just for growing new population, but also for increasing your manpower.
Explorers can turn invisible once you research Vacuum Protection, allowing them to effectively scout enemy territory.

Modules with effects highlighted in #C48594#Red#REVERT# scale depending on the size of the ship. Modules with effects highlighted in #6999D5#Blue#REVERT# scale with the size and level of the ship equipping them.
Modules that require strategic resources to use often have unusual effects that could turn the tide of a battle.
When invading an enemy with proper defenses chances are you'll need both an attacking fleet and either a manpower or siege fleet.
A Faction Pact benefits both empires involved, with the bonus given to you being determined by the faction you are signing a pact with.
Be careful not to let your diplomatic pressure get too high, if it reaches the minimum then the other faction can make a devastating demand. Declaring war will prevent/negate this effect.
Influence [Influencecolored] is used for diplomacy, laws, and powerful repeatable system improvements. Make sure not to use it all in one place.
Controlling a majority of the systems in a constellation will provide a powerful bonus.
Once the Unfallen [Unfallen] have vined a planet it can be hard to get rid of them since their vines slow enemy ships down and speed up theirs.
The United Empire [Terrans] has the ability to spend influence to instantly complete or purchase technologies, buildings, ships and resources.
The Nakalim [Templars] can build a Temple on a planet, allowing them to convert nearby systems very quickly. However, this comes at the cost of reducing the natural output of that planet by 50%.

The Hissho [MajorHisshos] can’t control many systems and compensate by mining planets with Behemoths [Juggernaut]. The economic gains from their unique mining abilities generally exceed those from colonization.

Minor populations will provide a special empire-wide bonus when there are 20 of them within your empire. Major populations will provide a powerful empire-wide bonus when there are 50 of them within your empire.

Boosting a population in the Population Overview screen will double the rate at which that population type grows, while also doubling its innate bonuses. Each population type has its own preferred resource you need to boost it with.
Every action you take will affect the political opinion of your citizens, take your actions carefully!

You do know best! Dictatorships choose which party gets to be in power, allowing you to easily switch to whatever party suits your empire's needs. In addition, they get a reliable set of always available independent laws!
Republic is a great government for empires with a lot of influence to spend, their laws are much more effective than anyone else's.
If you want to pass more laws at once (at reduced cost!), Democracy is an amazing government type.
If your empire is having trouble expanding past your colonization cap, the Federation government type could help.
Kinetic weapons will be mostly absorbed against well-armored ships, maybe try using some energy weapons instead.
Shields are fantastic for absorbing energy weapons, but don’t underestimate their value against kinetic weapons as well.
Beams are well rounded weapons good for almost every situation, but don’t have any notable strengths.
Missiles may provide a lot of damage, but they can be shot down by enemy flak. Maybe try mixing in some Swarm Missiles with your Missiles to confuse enemy flak.
Know your opponent hasn’t been manning their ships properly? Attacking ships with boarding pods kills the crew, and once all the crew is dead you will take the ship for yourself.
Ships get a bigger damage bonus the closer they are to being completely manned.
Critical hits will ignore enemy shields and armor, allowing you to quickly shred well-defended ships.
The Blast Effect Battery can be used to utterly decimate fleets with many small ships.

Make sure you manage Approval [approvalcolored] properly! Letting your citizens get unhappy could lead to revolt. Content citizens produce more food and influence on a system level and more dust and science on an empire level, with angry citizens producing less of these.
Curiosities aren’t just there to show you where resource deposits are, sometimes they have powerful weapons and buildings.
EMPs can be used to disable either an enemy’s weapons or shields. This can be a very powerful tool if you use it properly!
Invading systems can require a lot of time and effort, softening it up by sieging it for a few turns can make the battle go much more in your favor.
Minor factions are nothing to scoff at, some have powerful faction traits, others have powerful population. Acquiring them is always a boon.
Coordinators are great for absorbing powerful hits, and can be fitted with powerful modules that provide flotilla-wide buffs.
Pick your tactics cards carefully! Many have negative effects that could not only cripple your enemy, but also YOU if you use them incorrectly.
Don’t ignore your faction quest, it can provide you with powerful bonuses and abilities that will be useful to you the whole game.
You can manage your entire empire from the Empire Summary screen, without even having to look at the galaxy map.
Be careful when entering an Vaulter [Vaulters] territory, they can instantly teleport their ships from and to any of their systems.
Need to boost sheer production of ships and buildings quickly? The Industrialist Party [industrialistcolored] has the laws you need.
If you have a variety of strong population types or anomalies and want to make use of them, Ecologist Party [ecologistcolored] laws are ideal.
To dominate the enemy in battle and save on the costs of your navy, use the laws of the Militarist Party [militaristcolored].
The Pacifist Party [Pacifistcolored] laws are excellent for making new friends and turning a profit from galactic business like Luxuries and Trade Routes.
If you need to know your enemy and bypass their defenses, the Scientist Party [scientistcolored] can help you gain the advantage.
The Religious Party [Religiouscolored] can help you build a strong economy despite a lack of territory or resources by harnessing Heroes, special nodes, and the spoils of your enemies worlds.
Plan on killing a lot of ships in the near future? Modules and hero skills that provide a resource per Command Points destroyed could give you a powerful surplus of said resource.
Don’t have any planets left to colonize? Your colonization ships could be converted into siege or invasion ships that batter an enemy’s defenses!
Trade agreements give you access to luxuries produced by other empires.
Pay attention to the innate bonuses of your populations, it could be worthwhile to send them to a more effective system.
Mercenary Ships have an improved privateering, though at an increased cost. They can be used to attack Allies and players at peace without having to break it.

Hot [TemperatureHot] planets are great for producing industry, but tend to have terrible science. Next time you’re looking for additional industry, it may be a good idea to colonize a system with multiple hot planets.

Fertile [Rich] planets are the perfect climate for growing food and holding population. If you’re wanting to grow a lot of population and quickly, a Fertile planet is your best bet. Fertile planets tend to not produce as much industry or science per population though.

Cold [TemperatureCold] planets are the ideal planet type to set up some laboratories to produce research. If you’re ever feeling behind in the tech tree, a Cold planet might be the thing you need to catch up, though be wary that it will be hard to build up infrastructure.

Sterile [Poor] planets are good for specializing into a specific Fids [Fids] (exept food) determined by planet temperature. Though they tend to not have as many population slots as Fertile planets, they produce more Fids per pop slot.

Nakalim [Templars] players can’t produce science from planets, meaning cold planets are entirely useless to them. This is also the ideal place to build temples, since the malus doesn’t affect you nearly as much.

If you’re willing to wait, send a Warning and a Prepare for War declaration, and after the warning expires you will be able to declare war for very cheap. The best part is, if you decide it’s not worth waiting you can still declare a surprise war.
Finding diplomacy too expensive? Send a praise to another faction, it drastically lowers the cost of positive diplomacy.

All Trading Company headquarters will trade with every trading subsidiary, and vice versa. However, headquarters will not trade with each other, and similarly subsidiaries will only trade with headquarters.
Bombers [Bomber] do not take accuracy penalties and ignore enemy evasion, great for dealing with pesky Umbral Choir fleets.

Trade routes produce dust and luxuries primarily based on the level of development of the systems containing the headquarters and subsidiary. This enables them to scale as your overall empire develops!

Trade routes will generate luxury resources not only from the systems containing the headquarters and subsidiary, but also from the directly surrounding colonized systems. However, other systems along the trade route will NOT contribute luxuries.

The more industry [Industrycolored] something costs to build, the greater the dust cost to buyout [BuyOut], so buyouts can get very expensive very quickly. It’s more effective to buy out cheaper buildings than expensive ones.
The Vodyani [Vampirilis] can undock and mover their system somewhere else at any time, though it won't produce anything when doing so.
The Umbral Choir’s [UmbralChoir] beacons provide special empire-wide bonuses depending on which special node they are placed on! More beacons means more bonuses.
Economic Behemoths [Juggernaut] are powerful tools--just be sure to continue moving them to new systems so that they can help build up infrastructure in new locations.
Riftborn [TimeLords] ships may be fragile, but they make up for it in firepower. Riftborn ships have, on average, more weapons than any other faction.

Craver [Cravers] ships have 10% less hp then other factions, to compensate for this that can command larger fleets, an effective strategy for dealing with these swarms is to use AOE battle effects such as the blast effect battery heavy weapon and the collateral damage battle card, both found in the military tree.

Assigning a hero [Hero] to a system can be the difference between mediocrity and greatness, make sure to utilize them wisely. Similarly, assigning a hero to a fleet can be the difference between decisive victory and embarrassing defeat.
Finding the colors available to each faction to be too similar? Switch to the Saturated color palette in the settings.
All defensive hacking programs provide protection against one specific capital hack--be sure to choose wisely which outcomes are important to protect against.
Want to move populations between systems? System Modernization provides access to the spaceport, which allows you to ship populations to greener pastures.
Be careful, Pirates spawn in waves and can cripple an unprepared empire. However, if you are ready for their arrival, destroyed pirate lairs are can be an excellent source of resources.

The circles underneath a system’s name represent planets! Unfilled circles mean that you can’t currently colonize that planet, filled means that you can colonize it. If it has a ring, then it’s a unique planet with a resource bonus. If it’s colored, another empire has an outpost or colony on it.

The circles underneath a system’s name represent planets! If they pulsate every few seconds, then they have a curiosity for you to search. If it has a rotating line around it, a faction is currently mining it.

When looking in the galaxy view, the box behind a system’s name represents its system level. If it has no border, it is level 1. If it has a bright border on the top and bottom, it is level 2. If it has a bright border on all edges, it is level 3. If it is completely filled in with a bright color, it is level 4.
The more population you have, the higher the requirement to grow the next one, and the more food your system consumes. Make sure you invest in food or your empire will stagnate.
Ships kept in a system’s hangar will have less upkeep and heal faster, but can’t participate in any military operations.
It may be worthwhile to orbit an unused fleet around a special node. Some of them increase your vision range, give beneficial combat bonuses, or provide experience gain per turn.
Be careful when invading a Vaulter [Vaulters] system, they have higher defensive power than most factions.

The Unfallen [Unfallen] have one crippling weakness, if you take an Unfallen system, then all vined systems connected to it will be detached from the vine network and die! Taking the Unfallen’s home system means a guaranteed death for the Unfallen player.
If another faction has a system with an influence radius that covers your system, a great way to prevent them from converting it is by declaring war.
Remember, the Riftborn [TimeLords] can’t use food when creating outposts, instead, they value high industry-producing planets like Ash, Lava, or Burning Gas.

New populations are grown once you have an accumulated stock of 300 food (scaling with game speed). Any food over this number is counted towards growing the next population, but you can only grow one population per turn, this can be bypassed with the population cloning buildin and otherwise there are technologies that will convert excess food stock into other resources.
Mining Behemoths are great for gathering luxury and strategic resources that would otherwise be unavailable to you.

The Hissho [MajorHisshos] have the ability to add a portion of the Fidsi [fidsi] on each planet they mine to every planet on their home system, allowing their single system to experience the growth of an entire empire.
Science Behemoths are great for achieving a Science Victory, and can be used to lower the science costs of technologies.
The Academy [Academy] will grant its benefactors roles with powerful bonuses... to those who can win his auction.

The cost of technologies will slowly increase as you research more, Make sure you pick what you research first wisely. (this doesn't apply to technologies over the ammount required to unlock the next tier)

Systems can store up to one turn of Industry [Industrycolored], If you forget to queue up something to build, or you start on something that doesn't take industry to build, you'll be able to use it next turn!

You can store up to one turn of Science, [Sciencecolored] This means that if you forget to queue a technology for a turn, you won't take any penalties! This also means that any Science earned through destroying ships is lost if you earn more than you naturally produce per turn!
Don't Forget to boost your pop!
Independent [Politics] laws need to be unlocked by doing elections like any other party, the election result doesn't matter to them though.
Gas giants [Telluric] give the most Fidsi [fidsi] per pop, but suffer from a lack of pop slots and approval penalties.
The United Empire starts out industrialist [industrialist] but can pivot mid match to a Scientist [Scientist] or Militarist [Militarist] empire by completing their quest

Hero [Hero] Skills come in four types, Labour [MasteryLabour] which increases system yields on the system they're assigned on, Wit [MasteryWit] increases Empire yields on the system they're assigned on, Curiosity [MasteryCuriosity] increases a fleet's overal exploration power and Command [MasteryCommand] increases your fleets combat power.
